title: How can complex physical constants in the theory of relativity formulate new mathematical theories? - Quora

response.answer_text: How can complex physical constants in the theory of relativity formulate new mathematical theories? Ah, it’s Ahmad Mbark, once again on his quixotic search for the mythical complex constants. As has been explained to you multiple times before, the constants don’t matter anywhere near as much as the equations the constants appear in. And we’re all wondering why you’re on a quest to make things even more complicated, when your questions indicate that you don’t have a firm grasp on the current theories. Meanwhile, don’t you have a PhD thesis to finish writing, so you can get that PhD in particle physics your credentials claim you’re getting next year?

What is a “complex” physical constant? Physical constants are unitless numbers, like the fine-structure constant, approximately 1/137; or are numbers with units, so the number depends on what the units are. But I don’t know what would make a constant “complex”.Relativity either has no constants at all or has only the constants G (Newton’s constant) and c (speed of light). (In theoretical work, units commonly are chosen so that G = 1 and c = 1, hence, “no constants”.)Constants, physical or otherwise, “complex” or otherwise, do not give rise to mathematical theories.
